results.title: More Than Just a Game
results.material_description: Videogame, arcade machine handcrafted from reclaimed Australian blackwood, LED lettering, custom flooring
results.brief_description:
“Just like in the arcade games of the past, the government initiatives that exist are currently about us, without us. I want us to be seen, to have a say that enables us to take back control.”

Jarra Karalinar Steel conjures the nostalgic excitement of 1990s videogame arcades in More Than Just a Game. At its centre is The Adventures of Dolly, a playable game made with Wiradjuri and Ngiyampaa illustrator Charlotte Allingham. Take the controls and take Dolly on a journey through an alternate reality or not-so-distant future of Melbourne’s CBD, featuring iconic trams and Swanston Street.Growing up, videogame protagonists weren’t relatable to Jarra.

This work remedies that, giving First Peoples a chance to see ourselves imagined in a videogame – made for us, by us. Through The Adventures of Dolly, custom possum and wallaby spirit flooring and the hand-carved arcade cabinet, Jarra reclaims a place that hasn’t reflected our experiences. She brings Indigenous stories into gaming, inspiring the next generation and giving us power to determine our own futures.

constellations_primary.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

Game designed in collaboration with Charlotte Allingham

Game programmed by Peter Russell Adams

Arcade cabinet made with assistance from David Brophy

results.title: Gum preparation, stone flaking etc; (Episode 2)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: In 1965 and in 1967 the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies sponsored a film trip, but eh Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, to the Western Desert Region of Australia. The object of the trip was to film the daily life of nomadic Aborigines of the area. An attempt was made to locate groups still living in the desert. 63,000 feet of film were shot and in this record, or archival version of the material, every shot having ethnographic value is included. Film grammar has, in every case, taken second place. The film is divided into nineteen parts, seventeen of which were purchased for inclusion in the Film Library. Parts 3 and 11 were not purchased as they contain sacred material and , as such, are not suitable for use in schools. The seventeen parts which are in the library are more suited for used in secondary schools than in primary schools. However, titles will be recommended by Curriculum and Research Branch for use with the new Primary Social Studies Course. For general screenings, a condensed version has been made under the title of “Desert People”, catalogue number 2790. 3604. Part 1, 21 min, b&w. Seed-cake making and general camp activity. 3602. part 2, 19 min b&w. Gum preparation, stone flaking, Djagamara leave Badjar.

results.title: Seed cake making and general camp activity
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “People of the Australian Western Desert (A)”

Scenes typical of the daily life of nomadic Aborigines of the Pintubi tribe in desert conditions, filmed in the Clutterbuck Hills area, Western Australia. The women of the family group gather grass seed. Back in camp, surrounded by their family they make seed cake.

results.title: Art of the hunter
results.brief_description: Shows Aborigines making weapons, hunting, cooking and painting on bark. Also shows some rare cave paintings. Filmed in the Northern Territory near Darwin.

results.title: Australia's art of the Dreamtime: Quinkin country
results.creator_credit: Jim Needham and WIPB-TV, Ball State University
results.brief_description: An informative and educational documentary on the history of Australian Aborigines and their rock art in the Cape York Peninsula region of Queensland. The program explores not only the historical background of the rock paintings but theorises on the first arrival of Aborigines to this land and the formation of the landscape itself through archeological, geological and palaentological evidence. During the 1950s Australian artist and author Percy Trezise went on a quest to locate the rock art around Laura in the Cape York region and through contact with Aboriginal elders and befriending Aboriginal writer, Dick Roughsey, he was eventually accepted as a “tribal brother”. In this program, Percy, using images from his own paintings, interprets Aboriginal Dreamtime stories, mythology and initiation ceremonies as represented by the rock paintings. He speaks of his own experiences and respect for the Aboriginal people, their culture and their heritage. Voice over narration by Chris Schenkel. Note: Visual quality average - filmed on video camera.

results.title: Bridge over Myall Creek
results.creator_credit: Caitlin Shea, Margaret Parker, Wendy Page, John Millard, Helen Gasswill, Vanessa Gorman, Brigid Donovan, Samantha Butler and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Caroline Jones introduces this episode of “Australian story” which looks at personal reconciliation in action as demonstrated by the relationship between Sue Blacklock and Beulah Adams, descendants of victim and perpetrator in the 1838 Myall Creek massacre. Researching into her family history, Beulah Adams discovered her great uncle was one of the perpetrators in a massacre that saw 28 Aborigines killed. Beulah talks candidly about her reaction to the news, and her experience at meeting Sue Blacklock, descendant of one of the two survivors at a conference on reconciliation convened by Reverend John Brown. Another descendant of the perpetrators, Des Blake, talks about his experience at attending the memorial’s opening at Myall Creek in 2002, and how the experience has changed his life since then.

results.title: After trousers [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Richard Curson Smith, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, thirty-five years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode four examines the 200 year history of cross cultural appropriation since Aborigines first made contact with white settlers, a period referred to as “after trousers”. Particular attention is paid to the plight of Aboriginals in Tasmania, from King Billy and Truganini to the claim by current residents of their Aboriginal ancestry. Hughes travels to the home of the Bush mob, the last known group to have made contact with whites in 1984 before being reunited with the rest of their Pintubi community. He also visits Hermansburg Mission and speaks of the influence of Christianity, instilled by Lutheran missionaries over the years as well as touching on the forced removal of aboriginal children. He talks to opera singer Deborah Cheetham, one of the stolen generation, about her relationship with her biological mother and her thoughts on the matter.

results.title: Strike your heart
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker, Nicki Lukacs and Strike Your Heart Productions
results.brief_description: Strike Your Heart is a gentle portrait of change; its happiness and heartbreak for a boy, a family and a culture. It is 1967 and Australian Aborigines have won the battle for their citizenship rights. New attitudes are being embraced by all and for a ten-year-old boy (Rami Rahman) living in the quiet coastal town of Broome, North-Western Australia, there are personal challenges that have to be faced - falling in love, his first kiss, heartbreak and departure from his close-knit Aboriginal family. Filmed on location in Broome, Western Australia - Wayne Barker’s homelands, with an indigenous cast from the region, “Strike Your Heart” is the first indigenous drama made in Western Australia. Cast includes Jimmy Edgar, Petris Torres, Attika Edgar, Alison Torres, Sylvia Clarke, Stephen ‘Baamba’Albert, Emmanuelle Torres, Brian T. Eastwell.

results.title: Cunnamulla
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, ABC-TV (Australia), Camerawork and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The small outback town of Cunnamulla is situated in rural Queensland, 800 kilometres west of Brisbane. As one of the characters in this documentary says, “Cunnamulla is a town at the end of the railroad”, a once prosperous sheep farming territory that now has high levels of unemployment and petty crime. O’Rourke allows the people of the town to speak for themselves. The picture they paint is bleak; a town divided along racial and age lines, where whites and Aborigines are mutually suspicious of each other, where parents and grandparents can no longer understand the choices their children are making when it comes to sex, drugs and work. Filmed over the approaching Christmas period, “Cunnamulla” has its fair share of eccentric and stoic human beings, but the overriding impression is that the rapid pace of globalisation is exacerbating conflict and leading to the death of the very town itself. Whether it is in the doleful expression of a young man about to enter prison, or in the exasperated eyes of a father talking about his heavy metal obsessed son, O’Rourke’s film creates a vivid, powerful and disturbing portrait of outback Australia.

As one of the characters in this documentary says, “Cunnamulla is a town at the end of the railroad”, a once prosperous sheep farming territory that now has high levels of unemployment and petty crime. O’Rourke allows the people of the town to speak for themselves. The picture they paint is bleak; a town divided along racial and age lines, where whites and Aborigines are mutually suspicious of each other, where parents and grandparents can no longer understand the choices their children are making when it comes to sex, drugs and work. Filmed over the approaching Christmas period, “Cunnamulla” has its fair share of eccentric and stoic human beings, but the overriding impression is that the rapid pace of globalisation is exacerbating conflict and leading to the death of the very town itself. Whether it is in the doleful expression of a young man about to enter prison, or in the exasperated eyes of a father talking about his heavy metal obsessed son, O’Rourke’s film creates a vivid, powerful and disturbing portrait of outback Australia.

results.title: The Wik, the law & the land
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Latham and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The Labor Government’s Native Title Bill was passed in December 1993, acknowledging the entitlement of the Aboriginal people, in accordance with their laws and customs, to their traditional lands. The High Court’s Wik decision in 1996 removed long held assumptions about land tenure in Australia and created uncertainty in the minds of pastoralists and miners. Aboriginal groups however, believed that the decision would have little impact and that the farmers were generally over-reacting. Co-existence in the form of upgraded land tenure for the pastoralists and traditional access to the land for the Aborigines could lead to long-term stability - at least that was the aim of the Cape York Agreement. The Federal Government under the leadership of John Howard, found itself coming increasingly under pressure from the National Farmers Federation to nullify the High Court’s judgement and extinguish native title. This program examines the issues. Reporter: Murray McLaughlin.
